concept.title: XDCR filtering regular expression
concept.shortdesc: This is a list of JavaScript regular expressions (RegEx) you can use for XDCR filtering.

conbody.p: Regular expressions (RegEx) are a powerful way to match a sequence of simple characters. You can use regular expressions to create filters.
Regular expressions are case-sensitive: a lowercase 'a' is distinct from an uppercase 'A'. You can enclose a range of characters in square brackets to match against all of those characters.

row.entry: Might be used on a range of characters separated by a - character.
This is the "not" character, therefore [^0-9] matches against any character that is not a digit.

conbody.p: You can use ranges to specify a group of characters. You can also use the following shortcuts:

row.entry: Matches against a whitespace character (such as a tab, space, or line feed character).
Matches against a control character (for the hexadecimal character hh).
Matches against a Unicode character (for the hexadecimal character hhhh).

conbody.note: Since the backslash character is used to denote a specific search expression, if you want to match against this character you must enter a double backslash (\\).
conbody.p: To match against occurrences of a character or expression, you can use the following.

row.entry: Matches against zero or more occurrences of the previous character or expression.
Matches against one or more occurrences of the previous character or expression.
Matches zero or one occurrence of the previous character or expression.
Matches n occurrences of the previous character or expression.
Matches from n to m occurrences of the previous character or expression.
Matches at least n occurrences of the previous character or expression.

conbody.p: You can provide text to replace all or part of your search string. To do this, you need to group together matches by enclosing them in parentheses so that they can be referenced in the replacement. To reference a matched parameter, use $n where n is the parameter starting from 1.
